So awhile back Signal for Windows Desktop removed the ka-klunk sound notification and made it use the default Windows Notification sound. You can read more here - Replace custom notification sound with system sound by gasi · Pull Request #2108 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

This is causing problems for myself and other users.

How do we move forward with finding a dedicated sound for Signal for Windows or allowing customized sound notifications?

It really is unusual that Signal as a messaging app doesn’t have it’s own dedicated sound.

Skype, Slack, Discord, etc… all have dedicated and custom sounds so the user can identify which app is calling for attention. This makes Signal unusual and problematic since it is sharing the sound with common windows pop-up notifications (e.g. system tray notifications)

posts.cooked:
I’m on mac and like other OS, the desktop app uses a default system alert tone throught the notification center. However, that tone can’t be changed. The tone it uses is loud and annoying and I argue it’s not intended for a messaging app that might have a near-constant stream of incoming messages, issuing the tone for each one. It would be better if it used a different (or even selectable) system tone, one that’s less intrusive.

The details:
I have my system alert tone set in preferences->sound to ‘funk’.
But signal uses a different alert tone, it’s called a tri-tone sound, which is located here:
/System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/ToneLibrary.framework/Versions/A/Resources/AlertTones/sms-received1.caf

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

None of the notification service calls pass a true value to useTriToneSound and it defaults to the pop sound in that case.

That does seem to be accurate.

However, there is an evil JavaScript (and apparently TypeScript, too) trick at play there:

1236×82 14.6 KB

If messageId isn’t passed (or is otherwise a false-y string), the TriTone sound will be played.

I haven’t looked through the entire chain of passing messageIds around, but given that group call update messages appear to be sent without a message ID, I think it’s possible they might not have a message ID on the receiving side either, thus triggering the TriTone sound.

These group call update messages are described as “non-essential” though (because the receiving client can discover a change to a call by itself, e.g. when you open the group conversation view), not sure what notification sound, if any, would be played in that case.
